definitions.definition: To get back, to regain (a physical thing; in astronomy and navigation, sight of a thing or a signal).
definitions.example: After days of inquiries, he finally recovered his lost wallet.

definitions.definition: To salvage, to extricate, to rescue (a thing or person)
definitions.example: They recovered three of the explorers very much alive, then another, wracked with severe hypothermia, who was taken to hospital.

definitions.definition: To replenish to, resume (a good state of mind or body).
definitions.example: At the top of the hill I asked to stop for a few minutes to recover my strength.

definitions.definition: To obtain a positive judgement; to win in a lawsuit.
definitions.example: The plaintiff recovered in his suit, being awarded declaratory relief and a clearing of his name.

definitions.definition: To gain as compensation or reparation, usually by formal legal process
definitions.example: to recover damages in trespass; to recover debt and costs in a legal action or that is owing

definitions.definition: To restore to good health, consciousness, life etc.
To make good by reparation; to make up for; to retrieve; to repair the loss or injury of.
To get better, to regain health or prosperity
definitions.example: I lost out in the deal, but I quickly recovered financially

definitions.definition: To regain one's composure, balance etc.
definitions.example: Spinning round, he caught a stone with his ankle, but recovered quickly before turning to face me.

definitions.definition: (roofing) To add a new roof membrane or steep-slope covering over an existing one.
